awd_titl_txt: RUI: Adsorption and Surface Mediated Photo-Degradation Rate of Contaminants on Colloidal Natural Organic Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Mahamud Subir and his students at Ball State University explore the influence of Natural Organic Matter (NOM) on the transport and fate of emerging contaminants (ECs). ECs, such as pharmaceuticals and endocrine disruptors, are commonly detected in aquatic environments. NOM are particles suspended in environmental waters that consist of carbon-based molecules. NOM plays a role in aquatic pollutant distribution and transformation, but exactly how and to what extent remains unclear. This study focuses on finding the effect of NOM particle size and surface constituents on the uptake and photochemical breakdown of organic contaminants. The projects provide undergraduate students with a unique opportunity to perform hands-on experiments. The study creates information about binding strength of the contaminant molecules and NOM, and the rates of reactions that are mediated by the NOM surfaces. These findings help to explain the impact of ECs on our ecosystem and our health.   

This study uses both traditional and advanced laser spectroscopic tools in the areas of nano-, surface, and environmental chemistry. Second Harmonic Generation (SHG) and other analysis techniques isolate the surface effect from the bulk solution phase photochemistry of organic pollutants. The project develops model colloidal NOM using humic substances of distinct composition. The binding affinities of various ECs to the model NOM surfaces are measured. The rate of photolysis of both chemi- and physi-sorbed molecules at the NOM-aqueous interface is determined. In addition, the project investigates the influence of NOM size, solution acidity, and presence of reactive hydroxyl radicals on the processes of interest.  These results are expected to yield an extensive catalogue of adsorption equilibrium and photo-kinetic parameters. They also provide fundamental insight into the nature of specific EC-NOM surface interactions. This knowledge can potentially assist in developing remediation methodologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Due to over usage and improper disposal of pharmaceuticals, detection of pharmaceutical and other emerging contaminants in environmental waters is prevalent. Thus, the possibility exists for these micropollutants to inteact with various natural substances, such as natural organic matter (NOM), in the aquatic environments. NOM can exist as small particles suspended in water. The small size (in the orders of nano to micro meters) provides sufficient surface area for the organic contaminants to adsorb or accumulate in the interfacial region between the particle and the aquatic medium. This adsorption process and subsequent interfacial reaction driven by light can influence the distribution and chemical properties of these aquatic pollutants. Moreover, NOM consists of a wide variety of chemical functional groups. The effect of these chemical moieties on the interaction of pharmaceuticals had been relatively unexplored.  Putting these togeter, the question of how emerging contaminants, such as organic pharmaceutical pollutants, interact with the surfaces of particulate NOM has been addressed in this project.

Using a  laser-based surface selective technique and various complementary analytical tools, our group composed of undergaduate, highschool, and master's level graduate students explored the adsorption behavior of different types of pharmaceutical contaminants on chemical functionalities commonly present in NOM particles. Moreover, we have studied photochemical reactions of an organic dye adsorbed at a model NOM surface. The major findings of our research include: 

  • A surface group effect on the adsorpion of amlodipine (AMP) and carbamazepine (CBZ), two commonly detected pharmaceutical contaminants, has been elucidated. Interestingly, it is discovered that the molecular structural properties (i.e., rigidity, H-bonding ability) dictates the adsorption affinity and interfacial coverage.
  • The interfacial distribution of these compounds depend on the surface functional group of model NOM. For instance, AMP shows a greater extent of coverage on carboxylic based surfaces than that of amine functional group. The surface coverage of CBZ on these colloidal surfaces appears to be similar. 
  • We have also demonstrated that pharmaceutical compounds can adsorb onto the NOM via hydrophobic interactions and the binding affinity varies depending on the compound. For example, the driving force for the hydrophobic air/aquesous interface for 4 different emerging contaminants has been determined. Beta-estradiol and CBZ show the greatest proclivity and 4-propyl phenol, the least.
  • Studies involving hydrocarbon-based alkyl functional group, which represnts a hydrophobic surface, also demonstrated that hydrophobic interaction is a major mode of interaction with NOM for both AMP and CBZ. On the other hand, certain functional groups do not support adsorption of certain pharmaceuticals. CBZ, for instance, does not proclivity for the aromatic phenyl functionalized surfaces.
  • It is also discovered that photo-degradation of a certain organic dye is enhanced at the model NOM/aqueous interface. Malachite green, a dye pollutant, exhibits a faster breakdown rate under simulated sunlight compared to when it is dissolved in the bulk aqueous solutions.

These findings clealry show that interfacial chemical environment and adsorbate structural properties play a significant role on  adsorption of emerging contaminants and also on their chemical reactivity. Our research outcome thus generated new insights into the interfacial environmental processes involving NOM and selected emerging contaminants. Additionally, the experimental work paved the way for a new generation of  scientists to (1) learn and apply several advanced and delicate surface techniques, (2) become aware of environmental problems involving emerging contaminants, and (3) contribute to the scientific and general community through scientific publications, presentations and broader impact activities.

The project involved a total of 16 undergraduate, 2 high school, and 7 graduate (MS/MA) student participants. Of the total students trained and participating in the project, ~50% were female and ~36% among those underrepresented in STEM. Thus far, 2 MS theses have been completed and 2 MA degrees awarded based on this research.The work has led to 4 original articles in major peer-reviewed environmental chemistry journals. An American Chemical Society In-Focus E-Book motivated by this work has also been published. Moreover, the PI and his students have disseminated the results and outcome of this project via a total of 26 oral and poster presentations at various local, regional, and national conferences (e.g. ACS, NOBCChE, Indiana Academy of Sciences, and more).  A summer-long workshop, ?Early Navigation through Advanced Chemical Topics (ENACT),?  has been established at Ball State University (BSU), a primarily undergraduate institution. Thus far, a total of 28 students participated. As part of this educational activity, they had the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with cutting-edge instruments and learn advanced chemical concepts. With the help of faculty mentors, students learned different topics within the realm of chemistry. They explored their creativity through writing and creating short videos. The ENACT website displaying their work is online. A total of 21 Sci-blogs and 17 short videos generated by the students are currently showcased. Additionally, experiments developed based on this research have also been incorporated in a Physical Chemistry lab course.
